<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 101, 688, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 168, 581]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|> An object of mass \(m\) travels with speed \(v\) in a circle of radius \(r\). The force \(F\) acting on the object is given by <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 109, 539, 138]]<|/det|> \[F = \frac{mv^2}{r}.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 789, 183]]<|/det|> The percentage uncertainties of three of the quantities are given in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 196, 541, 214]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 227, 727, 338]]<|/det|>
quantitypercentage uncertainty
\(F\)\(\pm 3\%\)
\(m\)\(\pm 4\%\)
\(r\)\(\pm 5\%\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 529, 384]]<|/det|> The value of \(v\) is determined from \(F\), \(m\) and \(r\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 397, 181, 416]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 539, 415]]<|/det|> Calculate the percentage uncertainty in \(v\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 549, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
percentage uncertainty = .................................................... % [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 581, 181, 600]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 581, 425, 600]]<|/det|> The value of \(v\) is \(15.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 612, 517, 631]]<|/det|> Calculate the absolute uncertainty in \(v\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 736, 920, 755]]<|/det|> absolute uncertainty = ................................................. \(\text{ms}^{-1}\) [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 766, 920, 785]]<|/det|> [Total: 7]

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 776, 92]]<|/det|>
A steel ball is projected horizontally from the top of a table, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 103, 833, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 338, 591, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
The ball is projected horizontally at a speed of \(4.9 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The ball lands on the ground a horizontal distance of \(180 \text{cm}\) from the edge of the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 416, 447, 435]]<|/det|>
Assume that air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 144, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 448, 180, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 447, 660, 467]]<|/det|>
Calculate the time taken for the ball to reach the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 585, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
<form>time = ...................................................... $s$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 585, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 617, 181, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 617, 843, 636]]<|/det|>
Calculate the vertical component of the velocity of the ball as it hits the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 802, 920, 822]]<|/det|>
<form>velocity = .................................................... $m s^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 803, 920, 822]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude and the angle to the horizontal of the velocity of the ball as it hits the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 288, 920, 307]]<|/det|>
<form>magnitude of velocity = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[381, 319, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<form>angle to the horizontal = .................................................... .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 336, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 146, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
The ball is projected by means of a compressed spring which is attached to a fixed block as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 587, 534, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 634, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
The ball is placed on a frictionless track in front of the spring. The ball is then pulled back so that the spring has compression \(x_0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 680, 833, 699]]<|/det|>
When the spring is released, the ball is projected horizontally as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 712, 707, 856]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 873, 534, 892]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 892, 89]]<|/det|>
The variation with compression \(x\) of the applied force \(F\) for the spring is shown in Fig. 2.4.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 100, 781, 413]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 428, 534, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 784, 478]]<|/det|>
The ball is a uniform sphere of steel of diameter \(0.016 \text{m}\) and mass \(0.017 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 491, 183, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 691, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
<form>density = ............................................. $\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{m}^{-3}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 724, 180, 742]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 723, 920, 757]]<|/det|>
All of the elastic potential energy in the spring is converted into kinetic energy of the ball. The speed of the ball as it leaves the spring is \(4.9 \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 770, 776, 788]]<|/det|>
Show that the maximum elastic potential energy of the spring is \(0.20 \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 924, 920, 942]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 693, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 210, 888, 229]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 242, 181, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 242, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in **(b)**(iii) and the value of energy given in **(b)**(ii) to determine the compression \(x_0\) of the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 395, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<form>x_0 = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 427, 144, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
The steel ball is replaced by a polystyrene ball of the same diameter but of much lower mass. The spring is given compression \(x_0\) and is then released.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 710, 494]]<|/det|>
Air resistance on this ball is **not** negligible after it leaves the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 227, 523]]<|/det|>
Explain:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 181, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 311, 89]]<|/det|>
Define power.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 163, 181, 182]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 725, 182]]<|/det|>
Mechanical power \(P\) can be calculated using the formula \(P = Fv.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 194, 918, 212]]<|/det|>
Use the concept of work and the definition of power to show how this formula is derived.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 412, 146, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
The engine of a lorry provides \(130\mathrm{kW}\) of power to the lorry's wheels when it is travelling at a constant speed of \(25\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) along a straight horizontal road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 809, 476]]<|/det|>
Show that the resistive force opposing the forward motion of the lorry is \(5200\mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 660, 920, 678]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The lorry in **(b)** travels up a straight section of road that is inclined at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 116, 841, 243]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 265, 591, 282]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 295, 635, 313]]<|/det|>
The lorry has mass \(m\) and the acceleration of free fall is \(g\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 327, 180, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 327, 920, 359]]<|/det|>
Determine an expression, in terms of \(m\), \(g\) and \(\theta\), for the component of the weight of the lorry that acts parallel to the surface of the road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 450, 920, 468]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 482, 181, 500]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 482, 920, 530]]<|/det|>
The total resistive force remains unchanged at \(5200 \text{N}\) and the engine now provides greater power to maintain the speed of \(25 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The total mass \(m\) of the lorry is \(36 000 \text{kg}\). The angle \(\theta\) is \(1.4^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 543, 667, 561]]<|/det|>
Determine the power, in kW, now provided by the engine.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 790, 920, 808]]<|/det|>
<form>power = .................................................... $kW$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 821, 920, 839]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 850, 89]]<|/det|>
Polarisation is a phenomenon associated with light waves but not with sound waves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 181, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 102, 473, 120]]<|/det|>
State the meaning of polarisation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 134, 920, 153]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 920, 383]]<|/det|>
Two polarising filters A and B are positioned so that their planes are parallel to each other and perpendicular to a central axis line XY, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 395, 831, 616]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 635, 532, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 666, 900, 683]]<|/det|>
The transmission axis of filter A is vertical and the transmission axis of filter B is horizontal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 696, 920, 730]]<|/det|>
Unpolarised light of a single frequency is directed along the line XY from a source positioned at X. The light emerging from filter A is vertically plane polarised and has intensity \(I_0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 824, 91]]<|/det|>
Filter B is rotated from its starting position about the line XY, as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 95, 712, 120]]<|/det|>
After rotation, the intensity of the light emerging from filter B is \(\frac{1}{4} I_0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 127, 690, 146]]<|/det|>
Calculate the angle of rotation of filter B from its starting position.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 375, 922, 395]]<|/det|>
<form>angle of rotation = .................................................... °

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 407, 146, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 406, 920, 470]]<|/det|>
A microwave of intensity \(I_0\) and amplitude \(A_0\) meets another microwave of the same frequency and of intensity \(\frac{1}{4} I_0\) travelling in the opposite direction. Both microwaves are vertically plane polarised and superpose where they meet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 482, 181, 501]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 482, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
Explain, without calculation, why these two waves cannot form a stationary wave with zero amplitude at its nodes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 621, 178, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 621, 781, 640]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 839, 920, 857]]<|/det|>
<form>maximum amplitude = .................................................... $A_0$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 868, 920, 887]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 559, 91]]<|/det|>
A lepton is an example of a fundamental particle.

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 920, 231]]<|/det|>
A lambda particle \(\Lambda^0\) is a hadron that consists of an up (u) quark, a down (d) quark and a strange (s) quark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 546, 260]]<|/det|>
Show that the charge on the \(\Lambda^0\) particle is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 443, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 870, 462]]<|/det|>
The \(\Lambda^0\) particle is unstable. It can decay into a neutron (n) and a pion (\(\pi^0\)) as shown by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 472, 556, 492]]<|/det|>
\[\Lambda^0\longrightarrow \mathsf{n} + \pi^0.\]
